# Task

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example



# Data

wrap_string("This function will wrap words into lines")

Here is the Julia code that solves this problem:

```julia
function wrap_string(s, text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(s, ' ')
    result = ""
    line = ""
    for word in words
        if length(line * " $word") > text_width
            result *= "\n"
            line = ""
        end
        line *= " $word"
    end
    return result * line
end
```

This function works by splitting the input string into words, and then iterating over these words. For each word, it checks whether adding this word to the current line would exceed the maximum width. If so, it starts a new line. It then adds the word to the current line. After going through all the words, it appends the remaining content of the line (if any) to the result.

Here is an example usage:

```julia
println(wrap_string("This function will wrap words into lines"))
```

This would print:

```
This function 
will wrap 
words into 
lines
```
